awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Observing the Physics of Star Formation in Galaxies
awd_abstract_narration:
The team will use a new facility, the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), to observe the cold gas inside galaxies.  The team will study the details of how stars form in the cold gas.  These details will enable strong tests of competing theories of star formation.  Senior team members will mentor junior members, including undergraduate students who have disabilities.  The PI will engage high school students from Ohio in hands-on, astronomy-themed projects.

The team will use ALMA's unrivaled angular resolution, wavelength coverage and sensitivity to study the physical conditions in the cold gas inside galaxies.  Their goals are to (1) measure the variations in volume densities to test theories that posit gas density as the main driver of star formation; (2) make the first systematic measurements of the cloud-scale structure, density, turbulence, and self-gravity of the gas in a representative sample of galaxies; (3) model the life-cycle of star-forming clouds and constrain the dominant cloud destruction mechanism; and (4) develop, refine, and disseminate new methods to handle the complex data analysis.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported investigations of the physics of star formation in galaxies beyond our own Milky Way. The focus of the work was using multiwavelength observations of gas, recently formed massive stars, and the galaxies themselves to understand (1) the origins and properties of star-forming gas clouds ("stellar nurseries"), (2) how conditions in these stellar nurseries affect (or don't) the process of forming new stars, and (3) the timescales and physical mechanisms for the formation of stars from gas and the eventual dispersal of gas clouds by these newly formed stars.

Concretely the NSF funding has been essential to support efforts using the NSF-funded Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimiter Array (ALMA) to measure the properties of molecular gas across almost 100 nearby galaxies. This has provided our first-ever synthetic view of the population of stellar nurseries across the local galaxy population. The results showed how stellar nurseries reflect their parent galaxies, so that the environments where stars form must vary in important ways across the universe. The support was also critical to studies of the other phases of the interstellar gas related to star formation, including dense molecular gas, atomic gas, and dust. These observations provided the key backbone to make new measurements of the efficiencies and timescales of star formation mentioned above, and these measurements are now field standard numbers.

The support also was critical to expand research opportunities for high school, undergraduate summer, and graduate students at Ohio State. This included summer introduction-to-research training for both STEM-interested high school students and Ohio State undergraduates interested in research careers. Graduate students funded by the award have gone on to both Astronomy postdoctoral fellowships and careers in the data science industy. Tools and methods developed in the context of the award are now in use across relevant subfields, including a data reduction pipeline and analysis methods. The project also spurred new observational programs using NSF-funded facilities to address next big questions.
